String.Source:
[pagebreak]

Confessions of a Dunmer Skooma Eater

[pagebreak]

othing is more revolting to Dunmer feeling than the sorry spectacle of another Dunmer enslaved by that derivative moon-sugar known as 'skooma.' And nothing is less appetising than listening to the pathetic tales of humiliation and degradation associated with a victim of this addictive drug. Why, then, do I force myself upon you with this extended and detailed account of my sins and sorrows? Because I hope that by telling my tale, the hope of redemption from this sorry state shall be more widely known. And because I hope that others who have also fallen into the sorry state of skooma addiction may therefore hear of my story, of how I fell into despair, and how I once again found myself and freed myself from my own self-imposed chains. Because it is widely known to all Khajiit, who may be expected to know, that there is no cure for addiction to skooma, that once a slave to skooma, always a slave to skooma. Because this is widely known, it is taken to be true. But it is not true, and I am living proof. There is no miracle cure. There is no potion to be taken. There is no magical incantation which frees you from the thrill of skooma running through your blood. But it is through the understanding of that thrill, and the acceptance of the lust within oneself for that thrill, and the casting aside of the shame that the thrillseeker feels when he cannot set aside what becomes in the end his only comfort and pleasure, it is through this knowledge and understanding that the victim comes to the place where choices may be made, where despair and hope may be separated. In short, only knowledge and acceptance can deliver into the slave's hands the key that opens his shackles and sets him free.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

Confessions of a Dunmer Skooma Eater

[pagebreak]

Tidak ada yang lebih menjijikkan bagi perasaan Dunmer daripada tontonan menyedihkan dari Dunmer lain yang diperbudak oleh gula bulan turunan yang dikenal sebagai 'skooma.' Dan tidak ada yang kurang menggugah selera daripada mendengarkan kisah menyedihkan tentang penghinaan dan degradasi yang terkait dengan korban narkoba adiktif ini. Lalu, mengapa saya memaksa diri saya pada Anda dengan kisah panjang dan terperinci tentang dosa dan kesedihan saya? Karena saya berharap bahwa dengan menceritakan kisah saya, harapan penebusan dari keadaan menyedihkan ini akan lebih dikenal luas. Dan karena saya berharap orang lain yang juga jatuh ke dalam kecanduan skooma yang menyedihkan ini dapat mendengar cerita saya, tentang bagaimana saya jatuh ke dalam keputusasaan, dan bagaimana saya sekali lagi menemukan diri saya dan membebaskan diri dari rantai yang saya pasang sendiri. Karena diketahui luas oleh semua Khajiit, yang mungkin diharapkan tahu, bahwa tidak ada obat untuk kecanduan skooma, bahwa sekali menjadi budak skooma, selamanya menjadi budak skooma. Karena hal ini diketahui luas, dianggap benar. Namun itu tidak benar, dan saya adalah bukti hidupnya. Tidak ada obat ajaib. Tidak ada ramuan yang dapat diminum. Tidak ada mantra sihir yang membebaskan Anda dari sensasi skooma yang mengalir dalam darah Anda. Namun melalui pemahaman akan sensasi itu, serta penerimaan nafsu dalam diri seseorang terhadap sensasi itu, dan menyingkirkan rasa malu yang dirasakan pencari sensasi ketika ia tidak dapat menyingkirkan apa yang pada akhirnya menjadi satu-satunya kenyamanan dan kesenangannya, melalui pengetahuan dan pemahaman inilah korban sampai pada tempat di mana pilihan dapat dibuat, di mana keputusasaan dan harapan dapat dipisahkan. Singkatnya, hanya pengetahuan dan penerimaan yang dapat memberikan kepada sang budak kunci yang membuka belenggunya dan membebaskannya.

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

[pagebreak] The Poison Song Book II By Bristin Xel

[pagebreak]

ay felt no guilt, which frightened him. All through the long, fast walk away from the gorge, through the woods, across the dry creek bed, he chatted merrily with Baynarah, fully aware that he had just committed murder. Whenever his mind strayed from the conversation, and he thought back on the last moments of Vaster's short life, the Song would soar. He could not think of the boy's death, but Tay knew he was responsible. "You're a mess!" cried Aunt Ulliah the moment she saw the two children emerging from the woods onto the grounds of Sandil House. "Where have you been?" "Didn't Vaster already tell you?" asked Tay. The scene played itself out as Tay knew it would, every dancer in the Song performing their steps as choreographed. Aunt Ulliah saying that she had not seen Vaster. Baynarah, not yet frightened, making up an innocent lie about the threesome not having strayed far, saying he must have gotten lost. A slow but steady rhythm of panic intensifying as night began to fall, and Vaster had not yet returned. Baynarah and Tay tearfully (he was surprised how easy it was for him to cry without feeling) admitting where they had been, and leading Uncle Triffith and a crowd of servants to the junk pile and gorge. The tireless search through the woods as night turned to dawn. The weeping. The light punishment, merely cries of anger, that Baynarah and Tay suffered for losing their young cousin. It was thought, from their stricken expressions, that the children felt guilty enough. They were sent to bed at dawn while the hunt through the woods continued. Tay was drifting to sleep when his nursemaid Edebah came into his room. The look of unwavering love and devotion had not left her eyes, and he sank gratefully into his dreams and nightmares with her holding his hand. The Song wafted almost imperceptibly through his consciousness as he again had the vision of the room in the castle. The girl and her baby. The bird in the rafters. The dying fire. The sudden explosion of violence. Breathless, Tay opened his eyes. Edebah was stealing out the door, softly humming the Song to herself. In her hand was the crystal globe from his satchel. For a moment, he hesitated, about to cry out. How did she know the Song? Was she aware that he had murdered another boy to get the globe? Somehow he knew that she was helping him, that she knew all and loved him and sought only to protect him. The next day, and the next week, and the next month were all the same. No one spoke very much, and when they did it was to suggest new places to look for the missing boy. Everywhere had been searched thoroughly. Tay was curious why they never looked in the gorge, but he understood how inaccessible it was. A side-effect of Vaster's absence was that the tutorial sessions with Kena Gafrisi took on a more serious, even academic quality. The younger boy's high spirits and meager attentiveness had always cut the lessons short, but sensible Baynarah and quiet Tay were ideal pupils. He was particularly impressed by how focused they became during a rather dry history lecture about the heraldic symbols of Houses of Morrowind. "The crest of the Hlaalu features a scale," he sniffed disdainfully. "They see themselves as the great compromisers, as if that were something honorable. Many hundreds of years ago, they were the tribesmen following Resdayn who chose--" "Pardon me, Kena," asked Baynarah. "But what is the crest with the insect on it?" "You don't know House Redoran?" asked the tutor, lifting up one of the shields. "I know you have a sheltered life on Gorne, but you're surely old enough to recognize--" "Not that one, Kena," replied Tay. "I think she means the other crest with an insect." "I see," nodded Kena Gafrisi, brow furrowed. "Yes, you would be too young to have ever seen the crest of the Sixth House, the House of Dagoth. Our enemies together with the accursed heretical Dwemer in the War of the Red Mountain, now totally destroyed, thanks be to Lord, Mother, and Wizard. That House was a curse on our land for millennia, and when at last their pestilence was snuffed out, the very earth itself breathed a cloud of fire and ash in relief, bringing night to day for over a year's time." Baynarah and Tay knew they could not speak, but they exchanged knowing glances at one another as the tutor enlarged on the theme of the great wickedness of the Dwemer and the House Dagoth. As soon as the lesson ended, they walked silently out of Sandil House until they were far from all ears and eyes. The afternoon sun stretched out the shadows of the spear-like trees surrounding the meadow. Off in the distance, they could hear the sounds of the workers beginning their preparations for the autumntide harvest, yelling to one another unintelligibly in coarse and familiar accents. "That was definitely the symbol on that shield you found at the garbage heap," Baynarah said at last. "Everything there must be a remnant of the House Dagoth." Tay nodded. His mind was on the strange crystal globe. He felt a light vibration of soundless music touch his body, and knew he was discovering a new cadence of the Song. "Why would our people have burned and discarded all that?" he asked thoughtfully. "Do you think the House Dagoth was so evil that everything associated with them could have been cursed?" Baynarah laughed. At the height of day, all talk of curses and the evil Sixth House were pure supposition: something to add romance to one's life, but nothing to worry about. The two children walked back to the castle for yet another in a series of cold, quiet dinners. As the night fell, Baynarah looked through the treasures she had picked up in the junk heap. By the light of the moons, the small jars, the torc with orange gemstones, the bits of tarnished silver and gold of no obvious purpose, all took on a sinister aspect. Revulsion overtook her feeling of admiration instantly. There was a strange energy to them, a tincture of death and corruption that was undeniable. Baynarah ran to the window and vomited. Looking out to the dark open lawn below, she saw a figure below lighting an arrangement of candles in the shape of a large insect, the symbol of the House Dagoth. When it looked in her direction, she pulled back, but she saw the face illuminated by the tallows. It was Edebah, Tay's nursemaid. The next morning, Baynarah left the castle grounds early, bearing a large sack filled with her treasures. She carried them to the dumping ground and left them there. Then she returned, and told her Uncle Triffith what she had seen the night before, leaving out only what had made her sick in the first place. Edebah was banished from the isle of Gorne without discussion. She wept, begging to be allowed to say goodbye to Tay, but all believed that would be too dangerous. When Tay asked what had become of her, he was told she had to return to her family on the mainland. He had grown too old for a nursemaid. Baynarah never told him what she knew. For she was afraid.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

[pagebreak] The Poison Song Book II By Bristin Xel

[pagebreak]

Tay tidak merasakan rasa bersalah, yang membuatnya takut. Sepanjang perjalanan panjang dan cepat menjauh dari jurang, melalui hutan, melintasi dasar sungai kering, dia mengobrol ceria dengan Baynarah, sepenuhnya menyadari bahwa dia baru saja melakukan pembunuhan. Setiap kali pikirannya melantur dari percakapan, dan ia mengingat kembali momen terakhir kehidupan singkat Vaster, Lagu itu akan mengalun. Ia tidak bisa memikirkan kematian anak laki-laki itu, tetapi Tay tahu bahwa ia bertanggung jawab. "Kau berantakan!" teriak Bibi Ulliah begitu ia melihat dua Children muncul dari hutan ke halaman Sandil House. "Di mana kalian?" "Bukankah Vaster sudah memberitahumu?" tanya Tay. Pentas tersebut terjadi sebagaimana Tay ketahui, setiap penari dalam Lagu mengeksekusi langkah-langkahnya sesuai koreografi. Bibi Ulliah mengatakan bahwa ia tidak melihat Vaster. Baynarah, yang belum takut, mengarang kebohongan polos bahwa ketiganya belum menjauh jauh, mengatakan bahwa ia pasti tersesat. Sebuah Slow namun ritme panik yang stabil semakin intens ketika malam mulai turun, dan Vaster belum kembali. Baynarah dan Tay mengaku dengan mata berkaca-kaca (ia terkejut betapa mudahnya ia menangis tanpa merasakan) tempat mereka berada, dan memimpin Paman Triffith serta sekelompok pelayan ke tumpukan sampah dan jurang. Pencarian tanpa lelah melalui hutan saat malam berubah menjadi fajar. Tangisan. Hukuman ringan, hanya teriakan Anger, yang dialami Baynarah dan Tay karena kehilangan sepupu muda mereka. Dari ekspresi mereka yang muram, dipastikan bahwa Children cukup merasa bersalah. Mereka dikirim ke tempat tidur saat fajar sementara The Hunt melalui hutan terus berlanjut. Tay hampir terlelap ketika perawatnya, Edebah, memasuki kamarnya. Tatapan penuh cinta dan pengabdian yang tak tergoyahkan belum lepas dari matanya, dan ia bersyukur tenggelam dalam mimpi dan mimpi buruknya sambil memegang tangannya. Lagu itu melayang hampir tak terasa melalui kesadarannya saat ia kembali melihat visi kamar di dalam istana. Gadis itu dan bayinya. Burung di balok kayu. Api yang sekarat. Ledakan tiba‑tiba kekerasan. Tanpa napas, Tay membuka matanya. Edebah keluar pelan-pelan, pelan‑pelan bersenandung Lagu untuk dirinya sendiri. Di tangannya terdapat bola kristal dari tasnya. Sesaat, ia ragu, hampir berteriak. Bagaimana dia tahu Lagu itu? Apakah dia menyadari bahwa ia telah membunuh anak laki‑laki lain untuk mendapatkan bola itu? Entah bagaimana ia tahu bahwa dia membantunya, bahwa dia mengetahui segalanya dan mencintainya serta hanya ingin melindunginya. Hari berikutnya, minggu berikutnya, bahkan bulan berikutnya semuanya sama. Tidak ada yang banyak bicara, dan ketika mereka berbicara itu hanya untuk menyarankan tempat baru mencari anak yang hilang. Setiap sudut telah diperiksa dengan teliti. Tay penasaran mengapa mereka tidak pernah mencari di jurang, namun ia mengerti betapa sulitnya mengaksesnya. Sebuah efek samping dari ketidakhadiran Vaster adalah sesi tutorial dengan Kena Gafrisi menjadi lebih serius, bahkan bersifat akademik. Semangat tinggi dan kurangnya konsentrasi anak muda itu selalu mempersingkat pelajaran, tetapi Baynarah yang bijaksana dan Tay yang pendiam menjadi murid yang ideal. Ia sangat terkesan dengan fokus mereka selama kuliah sejarah yang agak membosankan tentang simbol heraldik Rumah‑rumah Morrowind. "Lambang Hlaalu menampilkan timbangan," ia mencium dengan nada meremehkan. "Mereka menganggap diri mereka sebagai kompromisor hebat, seolah itu sesuatu yang terhormat. Ratusan tahun yang lalu, mereka adalah suku yang mengikuti Resdayn yang memilih--" "Maafkan saya, Kena," tanya Baynarah. "Tapi apa itu lambang dengan serangga di dalamnya?" "Kalian tidak tahu Rumah Redoran?" tanya sang pengajar, mengangkat salah satu perisai. "Saya tahu kalian hidup terisolasi di Gorne, namun kalian pasti cukup umur untuk mengenali--" "Bukan itu, Kena," jawab Tay. "Saya rasa dia maksud lambang lain yang memiliki serangga." "Saya mengerti," sambil mengangguk Kena Gafrisi, alis berkerut. "Ya, kalian masih terlalu muda untuk pernah melihat lambang Rumah Keenam, Rumah Dagoth. Musuh‑musuh kami bersama dengan Dwemer kedokteran yang terkutuk dalam Perang Gunung Merah, kini sepenuhnya dimusnahkan, terima kasih kepada Tuan, Ibu, dan Penyihir. Rumah itu merupakan kutukan bagi tanah kami selama milenium, dan ketika akhirnya pestanya dimusnahkan, bumi sendiri menghembuskan awan api dan abu sebagai kelegaan, menjadikan malam menjadi terang selama lebih dari setahun." Baynarah dan Tay tahu mereka tidak dapat berbicara, namun mereka saling menukar pandangan pengertian saat sang pengajar menguraikan tema kejahatan besar Dwemer dan Rumah Dagoth. Begitu pelajaran selesai, mereka berjalan berdiam diri keluar dari Sandil House sampai jauh dari segala telinga dan mata. Matahari sore memanjangkan bayangan pohon‑pohon berbentuk tombak yang mengelilingi padang rumput. Dari kejauhan, mereka dapat mendengar suara pekerja yang mulai mempersiapkan panen musim gugur, berteriak satu sama lain dengan aksen kasar dan akrab yang tidak dapat dipahami. "Itu jelas simbol pada perisai yang kamu temukan di tumpukan sampah," kata Baynarah akhirnya. "Semua di sana pasti sisa‑sisa Rumah Dagoth." Tay mengangguk. Pikirannya tertuju pada bola kristal aneh itu. Ia merasakan getaran ringan musik tanpa suara menyentuh tubuhnya, dan tahu bahwa ia menemukan ritme baru dari Lagu. "Mengapa orang kami membakar dan membuang semua itu?" tanyanya dengan penuh renungan. "Apakah kamu pikir Rumah Dagoth begitu jahat sehingga segala sesuatu yang terkait dengan mereka dapat terkutuk?" Baynarah tertawa. Pada siang hari, segala pembicaraan tentang kutukan dan Rumah Keenam yang jahat hanyalah spekulasi semata: sesuatu untuk menambah romantisme dalam hidup seseorang, namun tidak perlu dikhawatirkan. Kedua Children berjalan kembali ke istana untuk makan malam lain yang dingin dan tenang. Saat malam tiba, Baynarah melihat harta karun yang ia kumpulkan di tumpukan sampah. Di bawah cahaya bulan, toples kecil, kalung dengan batu permata oranye, pecahan perak dan emas yang berkarat tanpa tujuan jelas, semuanya tampak menyeramkan. Kebencian segera menggantikan rasa kagumnya. Ada energi aneh pada benda‑benda itu, nuansa kematian dan korupsi yang tak dapat dipungkiri. Baynarah berlari ke jendela dan muntah. Memandang ke halaman terbuka yang gelap di bawah, ia melihat sosok menyalakan rangkaian lilin berbentuk serangga besar, simbol Rumah Dagoth. Saat sosok itu menoleh ke arahnya, ia mundur, namun ia melihat wajah yang diterangi oleh cahaya lilin. Itu adalah Edebah, perawat Tay. Pagi berikutnya, Baynarah meninggalkan halaman istana lebih awal, membawa karung besar berisi harta karunnya. Ia membawanya ke tempat pembuangan dan meninggalkannya di sana. Kemudian ia kembali, dan menceritakan kepada Paman Triffith apa yang ia lihat malam sebelumnya, sambil menyembunyikan hal yang membuatnya sakit. Edebah diusir dari pulau Gorne tanpa perbincangan. Ia menangis, memohon izin untuk mengucapkan selamat tinggal kepada Tay, namun semua orang percaya itu terlalu berbahaya. Ketika Tay menanyakan apa yang terjadi padanya, ia diberitahu bahwa ia harus kembali ke keluarganya di daratan. Ia sudah terlalu tua untuk seorang perawat. Baynarah tidak pernah memberitahunya apa yang ia ketahui. Karena ia takut.

String.Source: Waterwalking. If you wear any four Relics of Ahzidal, +10 Enchanting.
String.Dest: Berjalan di atas Air. Jika Anda mengenakan empat Relik Ahzidal apa pun, +10 enchanting.

String.Source: Summons a spectral drum that plays for <300> seconds, improving Stamina Regen for you and nearby allies.
String.Dest: Memanggil drum spektral yang bermain selama <300> detik, meningkatkan Regenerasi Stamina untuk Anda dan sekutu di sekitar.

String.Source: Increases Frost Resistance by <50>% and Frost spell damage by <25>%.
String.Dest: Meningkatkan Resistansi Frost sebesar <50>% dan kerusakan mantra Frost sebesar <25>%.

String.Source: Captain Veleth was alarmed by the strange note I recovered from the ash spawn at the Attius Farm. The note mentions Fort Frostmoth, the ruins of an Imperial fort located southeast of Raven Rock. According to him, the fort's been abandoned ever since the eruption of Red Mountain. He's sent me to Fort Frostmoth to kill the author of the note, General Falx Carius, before the town falls prey to his threats.
String.Dest: Captain Veleth terkejut oleh catatan aneh yang saya temukan dari makhluk abu di Peternakan Attius. Catatan itu menyebut Fort Frostmoth, reruntuhan benteng Imperial yang terletak tenggara Raven Rock. Menurutnya, benteng itu telah ditinggalkan sejak letusan Gunung Merah. Dia menugaskan saya ke Fort Frostmoth untuk membunuh penulis catatan itu, General Falx Carius, sebelum kota itu menjadi mangsa ancamannya.

String.Source:
Words of the Wind

[pagebreak]

his is a volume of verse collected from Ashlander wise women. 'May I shrink to dust' is from the Ahemmusa Ashlanders of the Grazelands. May I shrink to dust In your cold, wild Wastes, And may my tongue speak Its last hymn to your winds. I pray for the herder That whistles to his guar at play. I pray for the hunter That stalks the white walkers. I pray for the wise one That seeks under the hill, And the wife who wishes For one last touch of her dead child's hand. I will not pray for that which I've lost When my heart springs forth From your soil, like a seed, And blossoms anew beneath tomorrow's sun.
String.Dest:
Words of the Wind

[pagebreak]

ini adalah sebuah volume puisi yang dikumpulkan dari wanita bijak Ashlander. 'May I shrink to dust' berasal dari Ashlander Ahemmusa di Grazelands. Biarlah aku menjadi debu Di padang tak berujungmu yang dingin dan liar, Dan biarlah lidahku mengucapkan Nyanyian terakhirnya kepada angin-anginmu. Aku berdoa bagi gembala Yang bersiul kepada guar‑nya yang sedang bermain. Aku berdoa bagi pemburu Yang mengintai para penjelajah putih. Aku berdoa bagi orang bijak Yang mencari di bawah bukit, Dan istri yang menginginkan Satu sentuhan terakhir dari tangan anaknya yang telah meninggal. Aku tidak akan berdoa bagi apa yang telah ku kehilangan Ketika hatiku tumbuh Dari tanahmu, seperti benih, Dan berbunga kembali di bawah sinar matahari esok.

String.Source: I agreed to fund Ralis Sedarys' ill-fated excavation of Kolbjorn Barrow, but when I returned to his mining camp, I found only blood and corpses. Deep within the barrow, I found Ralis performing a ritual that released Ahzidal, a powerful Dragon Priest I fought and defeated.
String.Dest: Saya setuju untuk mendanai penggalian malang Ralis Sedarys di Kolbjorn Barrow, tetapi ketika saya kembali ke kamp tambangnya, saya hanya menemukan darah dan mayat. Di kedalaman barrow itu, saya menemukan Ralis melakukan ritual yang membebaskan Ahzidal, seorang Pendeta Naga yang kuat yang saya lawan dan kalahkan.

String.Source: Flawless Amethyst + Salt Pile + Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Amethyst Sempurna + Salt Pile + Kapsul Laba-laba Albino

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

The House of Troubles

[pagebreak]

mong the ancient ancestral spirits who accompanied Saint Veloth and the Chimer into the promised land of Morrowind, the four Daedra Lords, Malacath, Mehrunes Dagon, Molag Bal, and Sheogorath, are known as the Four Corners of the House of Troubles. These Daedra Lords rebelled against the counsel and admonition of the Tribunal, causing great kinstrife and confusion among the clans and Great Houses. Malacath, Mehrunes Dagon, Molag Bal, and Sheogorath are holy in that they serve the role of obstacles during the Testing. Through time they have sometimes become associated with local enemies, like the Nords, Akaviri, or Mountain Orcs. Malacath is the reanimated dung that was Trinimac, Malacath is a weak but vengeful god. The Dark Elves say he is Malak, the god-king of the orcs. He tests the Dunmer for physical weakness. Molag Bal is, in Morrowind, the King of Rape. He tries to upset the bloodlines of Houses and otherwise ruin the Dunmer gene pool. A race of monsters, said to live in Molag Amur, are the result of his seduction of Vivec during the previous era. Sheogorath is the King of Madness. He always tests the Dunmer for mental weakness. In many legends he is called upon by one Dunmer faction against another; in half of these stories he does not betray those who called him, further confusing the issue of his place in the scheme of things (can he help us? is he not an obstacle?). He is often associated with the fear other races have of the Dunmer, especially those who, like the Empire, might prove as useful allies. Mehrunes Dagon is the god of destruction. He is associated with natural dangers like fire, earthquakes, and floods. To some he represents the inhospitable land of Morrowind. He tests the Dunmer will to survive and persevere. The worship of these four malevolent spirits is against the law and practice of the Temple. However, the Four Corners seldom fail to discover those greedy, reckless, or mad enough to serve them. By ancient Temple law and custom, and also by imperial law, the lives of witches and warlocks are forfeit, and Imperial garrisons join Ordinators and Buoyant Armigers of the Temple in tracking down and destroying these foul covens in the wilderness refuges and ancient ruins where they conceal their profane worships.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

The House of Troubles

[pagebreak]

Di antara roh leluhur kuno yang menemani Saint Veloth dan Chimer ke tanah perjanjian Morrowind, empat Daedra Lord, Malacath, Mehrunes Dagon, Molag Bal, dan Sheogorath, dikenal sebagai Empat Penjuru The House of Troubles. Para Daedra Lord ini memberontak melawan nasihat dan peringatan Tribunal, menyebabkan pertikaian besar antar suku dan Great House. Malacath, Mehrunes Dagon, Molag Bal, dan Sheogorath dianggap suci karena mereka berperan sebagai rintangan selama Pengujian. Seiring waktu, mereka kadang dikaitkan dengan musuh lokal, seperti Nord, Akaviri, atau Orc Pegunungan. Malacath adalah limbah yang dihidupkan kembali yang dulunya Trinimac, Malacath adalah dewa lemah namun pendendam. Elf Kegelapan mengatakan ia adalah Malak, raja-dewa orc. Ia menguji Dunmer untuk kelemahan fisik. Molag Bal adalah, di Morrowind, Raja Pemerkosaan. Ia berusaha mengacaukan garis darah House dan merusak gen pool Dunmer. Sebuah ras monster, yang konon tinggal di Molag Amur, merupakan hasil dari godaan Vivec olehnya pada era sebelumnya. Sheogorath adalah Raja Kegilaan. Ia selalu menguji Dunmer untuk kelemahan mental. Dalam banyak legenda ia dipanggil oleh satu faksi Dunmer melawan faksi lain; dalam setengah cerita tersebut ia tidak mengkhianati mereka yang memanggilnya, menambah kebingungan tentang posisinya dalam skema segala sesuatu (apakah ia dapat membantu kita? bukankah ia sebuah rintangan?). Ia sering dikaitkan dengan rasa takut Races lain terhadap Dunmer, terutama mereka yang, seperti Kekaisaran, mungkin menjadi sekutu yang berguna. Mehrunes Dagon adalah dewa kehancuran. Ia berhubungan dengan bahaya alam seperti api, gempa bumi, dan banjir. Bagi sebagian orang ia melambangkan tanah Morrowind yang tak bersahabat. Ia menguji kehendak Dunmer untuk bertahan hidup dan bertahan. Pemujaan keempat roh jahat ini melanggar hukum dan praktik Kuil. Namun, Empat Penjuru jarang gagal menemukan mereka yang serakah, sembrono, atau cukup gila untuk melayani mereka. Menurut hukum kuno Kuil dan adat, serta hukum Imperial, nyawa penyihir dan warlock menjadi taruhan, dan garnisun Imperial bergabung dengan Ordinators dan Buoyant Armigers Kuil dalam melacak dan memusnahkan perkumpulan najis ini di tempat perlindungan liar dan reruntuhan kuno tempat mereka menyembunyikan penyembahan profan mereka.
Amethyst + Pod Laba Laba Albino Rusak

String.Source: Dwarven Oil Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Minyak Dwemer Poda Laba-Laba Albino

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

Changed Ones

[pagebreak]

f all the et'Ada who wandered Nirn, Trinimac was the strongest. He, for a very long time, fooled the Aldmeri into thinking that tears were the best response to the Sundering. They cried and shamed our ancestors, especially the feminine Altmer. They even took the Missing God's name in vain, calling His narratives into question. So one day Boethiah, Prince of Plots, precocious youth, tricked Trinimac to go into his mouth. Boethiah talked like Trinimac for awhile then, and gathered enough people to listen to him. Boethiah showed them the lies of the et'Ada, the Aedra, and told them Trinimac was the biggest liar of all, saying all this with Trinimac's voice! Boethiah told the mass before him the Tri-Angled Truth. He showed them, with Mephala, the rules of Psijic Endeavor. He taught them how to build Houses, and what items they needed to bury in the Corners. He demonstrated the right way to wear their skin. He performed the way to walk to achieve an Exodus. Then Boethiah relieved himself of Trinimac right there on the ground before them to prove all the things he said were the truth. It was easy then for his new people to become the Changed Ones.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

Changed Ones

[pagebreak]

f semua et'Ada yang mengembara Nirn, Trinimac adalah yang terkuat. Ia, selama sangat lama, memperdaya Aldmeri dengan membuat mereka percaya bahwa air mata adalah respons terbaik terhadap Sundering. Mereka menangis dan mempermalukan leluhur kami, terutama yang feminin Altmer. Mereka bahkan menyebut nama Tuhan yang Hilang dengan sia-sia, mempertanyakan narasinya. Jadi suatu hari Boethiah, Pangeran Plot, pemuda cerdas, menipu Trinimac untuk masuk ke mulutnya. Boethiah berbicara seperti Trinimac untuk sementara waktu, kemudian mengumpulkan cukup banyak orang untuk mendengarkannya. Boethiah menunjukkan kepada mereka kebohongan et'Ada, Aedra, dan memberi tahu mereka bahwa Trinimac adalah pembohong terbesar dari semuanya, mengatakannya dengan suara Trinimac! Boethiah menyampaikan kepada massa di depannya Kebenaran Segitiga. Ia menunjukkan kepada mereka, bersama Mephala, aturan-aturan Psijic Endeavor. Ia mengajarkan cara membangun Rumah, dan apa items yang mereka perlukan untuk dikubur di Sudut-sudut. Ia mendemonstrasikan cara yang tepat untuk memakai kulit mereka. Ia memperagakan cara berjalan untuk mencapai Eksodus. Kemudian Boethiah mengeluarkan Trinimac tepat di tanah di depan mereka untuk membuktikan semua hal yang dikatakannya adalah kebenaran. Maka menjadi mudah bagi orang‑orang barunya untuk menjadi The Changed Ones.

String.Source: Flawless Sapphire Gem Damaged Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Permata Safir Sempurna Sarang Laba-Laba Albino Rusak

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

The Five Far Stars

[pagebreak]

his is a volume of verse collected from wise women of the Urshilaku Ashlanders. It consists of verses composed by Ashlander warriors, champions, and ashkhans, committed to memory by the wise women and transmitted down the generations. 'May I shrink to dust' is attributed to the long-dead poet and warrior Zershishi Mus-Manul. Rise from darkness, Red Mountain! Spread your dark clouds and green vapors! Birth earthquakes, shatter stones! Feed the winds with fire! Flay the tents of the tribes from the land! Feed the burned earth with our souls! Yet never shall you have your rule over me. Never shall I tremble or flinch from your power. Never shall I yield my home and hearth. And from my tears shall spring forth The flowers of grassland springs.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

The Five Far Stars

[pagebreak]

Ini adalah sebuah volume puisi yang dikumpulkan dari perempuan bijak Urshilaku Ashlander. Ini berisi puisi-puisi yang ditulis oleh prajurit Ashlander, juara, dan ashkhans, yang dihafal oleh perempuan bijak dan diturunkan dari generasi ke generasi. 'May I shrink to dust' dikaitkan dengan penyair dan prajurit yang telah lama mati, Zershishi Mus-Manul. Bangkit dari kegelapan, Gunung Merah! Sebarkan awan gelapmu dan uap hijau! Hasilkan gempa bumi, hancurkan batu! Berikan api kepada angin! Renggut tenda-tenda suku dari tanah! Berikan tanah yang terbakar dengan Souls kami! Tetapi tidak pernah kau akan memiliki kekuasaan atasku. Tidak pernah aku akan gemetar atau mundur dari kekuatanmu. Tidak pernah aku akan menyerahkan rumah dan perapiku. Dan dari rataku akan tumbuh Bunga-bunga mata air padang rumput.

String.Source:
The Doors of the Spirit

[pagebreak]

he Ancestors are among us. They are never farther away than the Waiting Door. The Ancestors are not departed. The dead are not under the earth. Their spirits are in the restless wind, in the fire's voice, in the foot-smoothed step. Pay heed to these things, and you will know your absent kin. Pay reverence through gift and prayer. Acquaint the Ancestors with your affairs, with your comings and goings, with your blessings and trials. From the Waiting Door comes your protection. Heed the spirits, who are the guardians of your hearth, teachers of wisdom, counselors of fortune, seers of fate. Each bone is a door through the wall of the world. Each bone is the road, with Wisdom and Power the travelers. Each bone is the ghost fence that guards us from evil. Honor the Ancestors upon your hearths, within your halls, in the community of your temples, in the solitude of your tombs. Guard your Ancestors from beasts, from thieves, from profane priest and sorcerers. Let no creature steal your spirits, for the plundered hearth is diminished, and the plundered tomb is shamed. Live in One World with your spirits. Honor the spirits within and without you. Do not grieve for the dead. Take shelter in their arms, and pay heed to their words.
String.Dest:
The Doors of the Spirit

[pagebreak]

Para Leluhur berada di antara kita. Mereka tidak pernah lebih jauh daripada Pintu Penantian. Para Leluhur tidak pergi. Orang mati tidak berada di bawah tanah. Roh mereka berada dalam angin yang gelisah, dalam suara api, dalam jejak kaki yang terhaluskan. Perhatikan hal‑hal ini, dan kamu akan mengenal kerabatmu yang telah lama tiada. Beri penghormatan melalui pemberian dan doa. Kenalkan para Leluhur pada urusanmu, pada kehadiran dan kepergianmu, pada berkat dan cobaanmu. Dari Pintu Penantian datang perlindunganmu. Dengarkan roh‑roh, yang merupakan penjaga perapianmu, pengajar kebijaksanaan, penasihat keberuntungan, peramal takdir. Setiap tulang adalah pintu melalui dinding dunia. Setiap tulang adalah jalan, dengan Kebijaksanaan dan Kekuatan sebagai pelaku perjalanan. Setiap tulang adalah pagar hantu yang melindungi kita dari kejahatan. Hormati para Leluhur di atas perapianmu, di dalam aula mu, dalam komunitas kuilmu, dalam kesendirian makammu. Lindungi para Leluhur dari binatang buas, dari pencuri, dari pendeta dan penyihir yang tidak suci. Jangan biarkan makhluk apapun mencuri rohmu, karena perapian yang dirampas menjadi lemah, dan makam yang dirampas menjadi aib. Berjilah dalam Satu Dunia bersama rohmu. Hormati roh di dalam dan di luar dirimu. Jangan berduka atas orang mati. Cari perlindungan dalam pelukan mereka, dan perhatikan kata‑kata mereka.

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

Bone, Part II By Tavi Dromio

[pagebreak] "What do you mean the story gets more appalling?" Garaz was incredulous. "How in Boethiah's name could it get more appalling?" "It's a ruse," Xiomara scoffed, ordering two more mugs of greef and a glass of flin for Garaz. "How much worse can a tale get which prominently features cannibalism, abuse of slaves, and the regular placement of rotting animal carcasses?" "Don't you dare dare me," growled Hallgerd, annoyed by his listeners' lack of appreciation of his prose styling. "Remind me where we were?" "Arslic Oan is the owner of a stronghold under siege by savage, cannibalistic Nords," said Xiomara, keeping a straight face. "After a lot of deaths and several unsuccessful attempts to get water, he had his armorer with the unlikely name of Gorkith outfit his slaves with the first ever bonemold armor. One of them finally makes it back with some water." It was only one jarful of water (said Hallgerd, pulling back in his chair and continuing the tale), and Arslic Oan drank most of it, passing the remains to his dear armorer Gorkith and the last dribbles to the few dozen slaves who still lived. It was hardly enough to sustain health and well-being. Another expedition was necessary, but they had only one suit of bonemold left, as there was only one survivor of the trip. "One out of eighteen slaves made it through the gauntlet of Nords wearing that marvelous bonemold armor of yours," said Arslic Oan to Gorkith. "And one can only carry back enough water for one. Therefore, mathematically, as we have, counting you and me, fifty-six remaining people at the stronghold, we need armor for fifty-four. Since we already have one, you only need to make fifty-three to make the total. That way, three will make it back, with enough water for you and me and whoever's in the best condition to partake. I don't know what we'll do after that, but if we wait, we won't have enough slaves to fetch even a couple days' worth of water." "I understand," whimpered Gorkith. "But how am I going to make the armor? I used all the livestock bones to make the first batch of bonemold." Arslic Oan gave an order which Gorkith fearfully complied with. In eighteen hours - "What do you mean 'Arslic Oan gave an order which Gorkith fearfully complied with'?" asked Xiomara. "What was the order?" "All will be clear," smiled Hallgerd. "I have to chose what to reveal and what to conceal. Such is the way of the tale teller." In eighteen hours, Gorkith had fifty-three suits of bonemail (said Hallgerd, continuing, not really minding the interruption) prepared for the slaves. Without prompting, he ordered the slaves to practice using the armor, and even allowed them more training time than their predecessors. They not only learned how to move and stop quickly in bonemold, but how to adjust their peripheral vision to see a blow before it came, and to sway to dodge, and where the sturdiest reinforcement points on the arm were -- the center of the chest and the abdomen -- and how to position themselves to take blows there, against their natural instincts. The slaves even had time for a mock battle before being sent out among the cannibals. The slaves handled themselves admirably. Very few, just fifteen slaves, were killed and eaten out right. Only ten were killed and eaten when they reached the river. That was when things did not go according to Arslic Oan's plans. Twenty-one slaves with jars of water took off for the hills. Only eight returned to the castle, largely because they were blocked by the cannibal Nords. It was a larger percentage than he had anticipated surviving, but Arslic Oan felt righteous indignation at the paucity of loyalty. "Are you absolutely certain you wouldn't rather flee?" he hollered from the battlements. Finally, he allowed the survivors in. Three had been killed waiting for the gate to open. Two more died almost upon stepping into the courtyard. One was delirious, walking around in circles, laughing and dancing before suddenly collapsing. That meant five jars of water for four people, the two surviving slaves, Arslic Oan, and Gorkith. As the lord of the manor, Arslic Oan took the extra jar, but he was democratic with the others. "You're quite correct," frowned Garaz. "This story is getting more and more appalling." "Just wait," smiled Hallgerd. The next morning (Hallgerd continued) Arslic Oan awoke to a perfectly still and quiet stronghold. There was no murmuring in the corridors, no sound of hard labor in the courtyard. He dressed and surveyed the scene. It appeared that the fortress was utterly deserted. Arslic Oan walked down to the armorer's quarters, but the door was locked. "Open up," said Arslic Oan, patiently. "We need to speak. Thirty out of fifty-four slaves successfully made it to the river and gathered water. Admittedly, some then fled, and a couple didn't survive because I needed to correct their fickleness, but mathematically, that's a fifty-five percent survival rate. If you and I and the two remaining slaves made the next run to the river, we two should survive." "Zilian and Gelo left last night with their armor," cried Gorklith through the door. "Who are Zilian and Gelo?" "The two remaining slaves! They don't remain anymore!" "Well, that's vexing," said Arslic Oan. "Still we must continue on. Mathematically--" "I heard something last night," whimpered Gorklith in a funny voice. "Like footsteps, only different, and they were moving through the walls. And there were voices too. They sounded strange, like they couldn't move their jaws very well, but I knew one." Arslic Oan sighed, humoring his poor armorer: "And who was it?" "Ponik." "And who is Ponik?" "One of the slaves that died when the Nords poisoned our water. One of the many, many slaves that died, and we made use of. He was always a nice, uncomplaining fellow, that's why I noticed his voice above all the others," Gorklith began to sob. "I understood what he was saying." "Which was what?" asked Arslic Oan with a sigh. "'Give me back my bones!'" Gorklith's voice shrieked. There was silence for a moment, and then more hysterical sobbing. "I saw that coming," laughed Xiomara. There was nothing more to be done with the armorer for the time being (said Hallgerd, a trifle annoyed at the regular interruptions), so Arslic Oan stripped one of the dead slaves of his suit of bonemold and put it on. He practiced in the courtyard, impressing himself with his natural comfortably with medium weight armor. For hours, he boxed, feinted, dodged, sprinted, skipped, jumped, and generally cavorted about. When he felt tired, he retired to the shade and took a nap. The sound of the king's trumpet woke him with a start. Night had fallen, and for a moment, he thought he had been dreaming. Then the alarum sounded again, far in the distance, but clear. Arslic Oan leapt to his feet and ran to the ramparts. Several miles away, he could see the emissaries and their vast and well-armed escort approach. They were there early! The cannibal Nords below looked at one another with consternation. Savages they might be, but they knew when a superior force was approaching. Arslic Oan joyously dashed down the stairs to Gorklith's chamber. The door was still locked. He beat on it, cajoling, demanding, threatening. Finally, he found a key, one of the few scraps of metal that had not been smelted days before. Gorklith appeared to be sleeping, but as Arslic Oan approached, he noticed that the armorer's mouth and eyes were wide open and his arms were folded unnaturally behind his back. On closer inspection, the armorer was obviously dead. What was more, his face and whole body were sunken, like an empty pig's bladder. Something moved through the walls, like a footfall only... squishy. Arslic Oan expertly and gracefully turned to face it, completely in balance. At first, it seemed like nothing more than a bubble expanding through one of the cracks in the stone. As more of the flesh-colored gelatinous matter emerged, it more clearly resembled part of a face. A flaccid, almost shapeless face with a low brow and a slack, toothless jaw. The rest of the body oozed out of the crack, a soft bag of muscle and blood. Behind Arslic Oan and to the side, there was more movement, more slaves welling up through the cracks in the stone. They were all around him, reaching out. "Give us," moaned Ponik, his tongue rolling about his hanging jaw. "Give us back our bones." Arslic Oan began to rip off his bonemold, throwing it to the floor. A hundred figures, more, pooled into the small chamber. "That's not enough." The cannibals had cleared away by the time the king's emissaries arrived at Arslic Oan's gates. They had not been looking forward to this visit. It was best, they though philosophically, to begin with the worst of the king's noblemen, so to end their trip well. They sounded the alarum once again, but the gates did not open. There was no sound from Arslic Oan's stronghold. It took a few hours to gain access. If the emissaries had not brought a professional acrobat with them for entertainment, it might have taken longer. The place seemed to be abandoned. They searched every room, until finally they came to the armorer's. There they found the master of the manor, folded neatly, legs behind his head, arms behind the legs, like a fine gown. Not a bone in his body. "The first part of your story was complete nonsense," cried Xiomara. "But now it doesn't hold true on any level. How could bonemold be made again if the armorer who invented it died before he could tell anyone how he did it?" "I said that this was the first time it was created, not the first time people learned the craft." "And when did someone first teach someone else the craft?" asked Garaz. "That, my friends," replied Hallgerd with a sinister smile. "Is a tale for another night."
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

Tulang, Bagian II Oleh Tavi Dromio

[pagebreak] "Maksudmu cerita ini menjadi lebih mengerikan?" Garaz tampak tidak percaya. "Dengan nama Boethiah bagaimana bisa menjadi lebih mengerikan?" "Ini tipuan," Xiomara mengejek, memesan dua gelas greef lagi dan segelas flin untuk Garaz. "Seberapa buruk lagi sebuah cerita yang menonjolkan kanibalisme, penyiksaan budak, dan penempatan rutin bangkai hewan yang membusuk?" "Jangan kau nekat menantangku," geram Hallgerd, terganggu oleh kurangnya apresiasi pendengarnya terhadap gaya prosa nya. "Ingatkan aku di mana kita berada?" "Arslic Oan adalah pemilik benteng yang dikepung oleh Nords buas dan kanibal," kata Xiomara, tetap menjaga ekspresi datar. "Setelah banyak kematian dan beberapa percobaan gagal mendapatkan air, ia memerintahkan pandainya yang bernama Gorkith untuk melengkapi budaknya dengan baju zirah bonemold pertama kali. Salah satu dari mereka akhirnya kembali dengan beberapa air." Itu hanya satu toples air (kata Hallgerd, menunduk di kursinya dan melanjutkan cerita), dan Arslic Oan meminum sebagian besar, memberi sisa kepada pandainya yang tercinta Gorkith dan tetesan terakhir kepada beberapa lusin budak yang masih hidup. Itu nyaris tidak cukup untuk mempertahankan kesehatan dan kesejahteraan. Ekspedisi lain diperlukan, tetapi mereka hanya memiliki satu set bonemold tersisa, karena hanya satu orang yang selamat dari perjalanan itu. "Satu dari delapan belas budak berhasil melewati rintangan Nords sambil memakai baju zirah bonemold menakjubkan milikmu," kata Arslic Oan kepada Gorkith. "Dan hanya satu orang yang dapat membawa kembali cukup air untuk satu orang. Oleh karena itu, secara matematis, dengan menghitung kamu dan aku, ada lima puluh enam orang yang tersisa di benteng, kami membutuhkan baju zirah untuk lima puluh empat orang. Karena kami sudah memiliki satu, kamu hanya perlu membuat lima puluh tiga lagi untuk mencapai total. Dengan cara itu, tiga orang akan kembali, dengan cukup air untuk kamu, aku, dan siapa pun yang berada dalam kondisi terbaik untuk meminum. Aku tidak tahu apa yang akan kami lakukan setelah itu, tetapi jika kami menunggu, kami tidak akan memiliki cukup budak untuk mengambil bahkan air untuk beberapa hari." "Aku mengerti," Gorkith merintih. "Tapi bagaimana aku akan membuat baju zirah itu? Aku sudah menggunakan semua tulang ternak untuk membuat batch pertama bonemold." Arslic Oan memberi perintah yang dipatuhi Gorkith dengan takut. Dalam delapan belas jam - "Maksudmu 'Arslic Oan memberi perintah yang dipatuhi Gorkith dengan takut' apa?" tanya Xiomara. "Apa perintahnya?" "Semua akan jelas," tersenyum Hallgerd. "Aku harus memilih apa yang diungkapkan dan apa yang disembunyikan. Begitulah cara seorang pendongeng." Dalam delapan belas jam, Gorkith menyiapkan lima puluh tiga set bonemail (kata Hallgerd, melanjutkan, tidak terlalu memperhatikan gangguan itu) untuk para budak. Tanpa diminta, ia memerintahkan budak-budak itu berlatih menggunakan baju zirah, bahkan memberi mereka waktu latihan lebih lama daripada pendahulunya. Mereka tidak hanya belajar cara bergerak dan berhenti dengan cepat dalam bonemold, tetapi juga cara menyesuaikan penglihatan periferal mereka untuk melihat serangan sebelum datang, cara mengayun untuk menghindar, serta di mana titik penguatan paling kuat pada lengan—pusat dada dan perut—dan cara menempatkan diri untuk menerima pukulan di sana, melawan insting alami mereka. Para budak bahkan memiliki waktu untuk pertarungan simulasi sebelum dikirim ke antara kanibal. Para budak berperilaku sangat baik. Sangat sedikit, hanya lima belas budak, terbunuh dan dimakan secara langsung. Hanya sepuluh yang terbunuh dan dimakan ketika mereka mencapai sungai. Saat itulah hal-hal tidak berjalan sesuai rencana Arslic Oan. Dua puluh satu budak dengan toples air berlari ke bukit. Hanya delapan yang kembali ke kastil, sebagian besar karena diblokir oleh Nords kanibal. Persentase yang kembali lebih tinggi daripada yang dia perkirakan, tetapi Arslic Oan merasakan kemarahan yang benar atas kurangnya kesetiaan. "Apakah kamu benar‑benar yakin kamu tidak lebih memilih melarikan diri?" teriaknya dari benteng. Akhirnya, ia mengizinkan para penyintas masuk. Tiga orang dibunuh menunggu pintu terbuka. Dua lagi hampir mati saat melangkah ke halaman. Satu orang tergila‑gila, berjalan mengelilingi dalam lingkaran, tertawa dan menari sebelum tiba‑tiba jatuh. Itu berarti lima toples air untuk empat orang: dua budak yang selamat, Arslic Oan, dan Gorkith. Sebagai tuan manor, Arslic Oan mengambil toples ekstra, tetapi ia membagikannya secara adil kepada yang lain. "Kau memang benar," Garaz mengerutkan alis. "Cerita ini semakin mengerikan." "Tunggu saja," tersenyum Hallgerd. Pagi berikutnya (Hallgerd melanjutkan) Arslic Oan terbangun di sebuah benteng yang sangat tenang dan sunyi. Tidak ada gumaman di koridor, tidak ada suara kerja keras di halaman. Ia berpakaian dan meninjau situasi. Tampaknya benteng itu benar‑benar kosong. Arslic Oan berjalan ke kamar pandai besi, tetapi pintunya terkunci. "Buka," kata Arslic Oan dengan sabar. "Kita harus berbicara. Tiga puluh dari lima puluh empat budak berhasil sampai ke sungai dan mengumpulkan air. Memang, beberapa kemudian melarikan diri, dan beberapa tidak selamat karena aku harus memperbaiki ketidaksetiaan mereka, tetapi secara matematis, itulah tingkat kelangsungan hidup lima puluh lima persen. Jika kamu, aku, dan dua budak yang tersisa melakukan perjalanan lagi ke sungai, kami berdua harus selamat." "Zilian dan Gelo pergi tadi malam dengan baju zirah mereka," teriak Gorklith melalui pintu. "Siapa Zilian dan Gelo?" "Dua budak yang tersisa! Mereka tidak lagi ada!" "Nah, itu menyebalkan," kata Arslic Oan. "Tetap saja kita harus melanjutkan. Secara matematis—" "Aku mendengar sesuatu tadi malam," Gorklith berbisik dengan suara aneh. "Seperti langkah kaki, tapi berbeda, dan mereka bergerak melalui dinding. Dan ada suara juga. Suaranya aneh, seperti mereka tidak bisa menggerakkan rahang dengan baik, tapi aku mengenal satu suara." Arslic Oan menghela napas, menghibur pandainya yang malang: "Dan siapa itu?" "Ponik." "Dan siapa Ponik?" "Salah satu budak yang mati ketika Nords mem poisoned air kami. Salah satu dari banyak, banyak budak yang mati, dan kami memanfaatkannya. Dia selalu orang yang baik, tidak mengeluh, itulah mengapa aku memperhatikan suaranya di atas yang lain," Gorklith mulai menangis. "Aku mengerti apa yang dia katakan." "Apa itu?" tanya Arslic Oan dengan menghela napas. "'Kembalikan tulang-tulangku!" suara Gorklith berteriak. Terjadi keheningan sesaat, lalu sobekan histeris kembali. "Aku sudah melihat itu datang," tertawa Xiomara. Tidak ada hal lain yang dapat dilakukan dengan pandai besi untuk saat ini (kata Hallgerd, agak kesal dengan gangguan terus‑menerus), jadi Arslic Oan melepas satu dari budak mati itu dari set bonemoldnya dan memakainya. Ia berlatih di halaman, mengagumi dirinya sendiri yang terasa nyaman dengan baju zirah berat sedang. Selama berjam‑jam, ia beradu tinju, berpura‑pura, menghindar, berlari kencang, melompat, dan umumnya berkejar‑kejar. Ketika ia lelah, ia beristirahat di bawah bayangan dan tidur sebentar. Suara terompet raja membangunkannya dengan kaget. Malam telah tiba, dan sejenak ia mengira dirinya bermimpi. Lalu alarm berbunyi lagi, jauh di kejauhan, tapi jelas. Arslic Oan melompat berdiri dan berlari ke benteng. Beberapa mil jauhnya, ia melihat utusan‑utusan dan rombongan bersenjata mereka yang besar mendekat. Mereka datang lebih awal! Nords kanibal di bawah menatap satu sama lain dengan kebingungan. Mereka mungkin liar, tetapi mereka tahu bila pasukan yang lebih kuat sedang mendekat. Arslic Oan berlari dengan gembira menuruni tangga ke kamar Gorklith. Pintu masih terkunci. Ia memukulnya, memohon, menuntut, mengancam. Akhirnya, ia menemukan sebuah kunci, salah satu potongan logam sedikit yang belum dilebur beberapa hari sebelumnya. Gorklith tampak sedang tidur, tetapi ketika Arslic Oan mendekat, ia melihat mulut dan mata pandai besi terbuka lebar dan lengan-lengannya terlipat secara tidak wajar di belakang punggungnya. Setelah diperiksa lebih dekat, jelas pandai besi itu sudah mati. Lebih parah lagi, wajah dan seluruh tubuhnya cekung, seperti kantong babi yang kosong. Sesuatu bergerak melalui dinding, seperti jejak langkah yang hanya... lembek. Arslic Oan berbalik dengan mahir dan anggun menghadapinya, tetap seimbang. Awalnya tampak seperti gelembung yang mengembang melalui retakan batu. Saat lebih banyak materi berwarna daging muncul, jelas ia menyerupai bagian wajah. Wajah lemas, hampir tak berwujud dengan alis rendah dan rahang tanpa gigi yang kendur. Sisanya tubuh mengalir keluar dari retakan, kantong lunak berisi otot dan darah. Di belakang Arslic Oan dan di sampingnya, ada gerakan lebih banyak, lebih banyak budak muncul melalui retakan batu. Mereka berada di sekelilingnya, menjulurkan tangan. "Berikan kami," rintih Ponik, lidahnya berputar di rahang yang menggantung. "Kembalikan tulang‑tulang kami." Arslic Oan mulai melepas bonemoldnya, menjatuhkan ke lantai. Ratusan sosok, bahkan lebih, berkerumun ke dalam kamar kecil itu. "Itu tidak cukup." Para kanibal telah pergi ketika para utusan raja tiba di gerbang Arslic Oan. Mereka tidak menantikan kunjungan ini. Secara filosofis mereka berpikir, lebih baik memulai dengan yang terburuk di antara bangsawan raja, sehingga perjalanan mereka berakhir dengan baik. Mereka membunyikan alarm sekali lagi, tetapi gerbang tidak terbuka. Tidak ada suara dari benteng Arslic Oan. Butuh beberapa jam untuk mendapatkan akses. Jika para utusan tidak membawa seorang akrobat profesional untuk hiburan, mungkin akan lebih lama. Tempat itu tampak ditinggalkan. Mereka mencari setiap ruangan, sampai akhirnya mereka sampai ke kamar pandai besi. Di sana mereka menemukan tuan manor, terlipat rapi, kaki di belakang kepala, lengan di belakang kaki, seperti gaun mewah. Tidak ada satu tulang pun dalam tubuhnya. "Bagian pertama cerita kalian benar‑benar omong kosong," teriak Xiomara. "Tapi sekarang tidak lagi masuk akal di level apapun. Bagaimana bonemold bisa dibuat lagi jika pandai besi yang menemukan itu mati sebelum sempat memberi tahu cara pembuatannya?" "Aku katakan ini pertama kali diciptakan, bukan pertama kali orang belajar kerajinan itu." "Dan kapan seseorang pertama kali mengajarkan orang lain kerajinan itu?" tanya Garaz. "Itu, sahabat‑sahabatku," jawab Hallgerd dengan senyum sinis. "Adalah cerita untuk malam lain."

String.Source: Amethyst Gem Damaged Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Permata Ametis Pod Laba-laba Albino Rusak

String.Source: Flawless Sapphire Gem Salt Pile Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Flawless Sapphire Gem Salt Pile Albino Spider Pod

String.Source: I agreed to fund Ralis Sedarys' expedition to excavate Kolbjorn Barrow, but work on the dig has come to a halt. The excavation had reached a dead end when Draugr within the tomb awoke, killing several miners and causing the rest to flee. I found a way past the dead end, but must deal with the Draugr before work can continue.
String.Dest: Saya setuju untuk mendanai ekspedisi Ralis Sedarys untuk menggali Barrow Kolbjorn, namun pekerjaan penggalian telah terhenti. Penggalian mencapai jalan buntu ketika Draugr di dalam makam bangun, menewaskan beberapa penambang dan membuat sisanya melarikan diri. Saya menemukan cara melewati kebuntuan itu, tetapi harus menangani Draugr sebelum pekerjaan dapat dilanjutkan.

String.Source:
<font face='$HandwrittenFont'> <font size='17'>She's finally done it. I knew she'd eventually crack. I probably should have left when I had the chance. The untapped power within these spiders has finally gone to Merilar's head. Who would have thought these tiny albino creatures had the ability to harness such magic?
Being locked in this cage is frustrating, of course, but it is keeping me even more focused on my work. What did she think I was going to do, anyway? As my sister, she must have known how devoted I am to this work. Although, I can't fault her for her actions right now. Who knows what kind of fumes these experiments have been giving off, or what effect they have on the human brain. At least I'm all right. Or maybe I'm not but I think I am? Could these experiments be having the same effect on me that they are on her? [pagebreak] Magnificent! It seems as though you can combine any one of the base spiders with a modifier to tweak its behavior. For instance, just imbuing an Albino Pod with a Ruby seems to create a spider that jumps at its victims and proceeds to explode. But, by simply adding a Salt Pile to the mix it creates the same manner of spider, but instead of jumping and exploding it emits flames from its body. I'd experiment with more of these behaviors, but it seems the bandits we tested the mind control spiders on are all still locked away, Merilar doesn't want me to let them out. Maybe there are too many in there for her to handle?
I heard her muttering to herself earlier today. She was saying things like, "The spiders are mine. They'll listen to me!" What exactly is she planning? I hope she's not attempting to enter the blocked off room in the main chamber. She knows we specifically sealed it after hearing odd chanting coming from that direction. Then again, what she used to "know" may not matter right now, considering the state she's been in. I hope she'll be all right.

String.Source: Amethyst Gem Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Gema Ametis Kapsul Laba-laba Albino

String.Source:
<font face='$HandwrittenFont'> <font size='17'>I know what he's planning. Does he really think he can take all the credit for discovering these spiders? Next time he goes into the safety cage to do whatever it is he does with those spiders, I'll lock the door. He'll have no choice but to listen to me then.
What does he mean about me not being right in the head? There's nothing wrong with me. He's the one trying to steal my discovery! Does he think I don't see what he's doing? There's nothing wrong with me. Nothing! [pagebreak] He keeps talking to me like I'm insane. I'm not insane! Who said I'm insane? Did I say I was insane? I'll show him insane!
It doesn't matter. He'll see what real power is. The chanting we heard just outside the main chamber must mean there's something extremely powerful there. If I can get my hands on that energy and bring it back, who knows what kind of discoveries we can make from it.
String.Dest:
<font face='$HandwrittenFont'> <font size='17'>Aku tahu apa yang dia rencanakan. Apakah dia benar-benar mengira dia bisa mengambil semua pujian atas penemuan laba-laba ini? Lain kali dia masuk ke dalam kandang keamanan untuk melakukan apa pun yang dia lakukan dengan laba-laba itu, aku akan mengunci pintunya. Dia tidak akan punya pilihan selain mendengarkan perintahku.
Apa maksudnya tentang aku tidak waras? Tidak ada yang salah dengan diriku. Dia lah yang mencoba mencuri penemuanku! Apakah dia mengira aku tidak melihat apa yang dia lakukan? Tidak ada yang salah dengan diriku. Tidak ada! [pagebreak] Dia terus berbicara kepadaku seolah-olah aku gila. Aku tidak gila! Siapa yang bilang aku gila? Apakah aku pernah mengatakan bahwa aku gila? Aku akan menunjukkan kepadanya siapa yang gila!
Tidak peduli. Dia akan melihat apa itu kekuatan sejati. Nyanyian yang kami dengar tepat di luar ruang utama pasti berarti ada sesuatu yang sangat kuat di sana. Jika aku bisa mendapatkan energi itu dan membawanya kembali, siapa yang tahu penemuan apa yang bisa kami buat darinya.

String.Source: I agreed to continue funding Ralis Sedarys' excavation of Kolbjorn Barrow. I should return and see how the work is going.
String.Dest: Saya setuju untuk terus mendanai penggalian Ralis Sedarys di Barrow Kolbjorn. Saya harus kembali dan melihat bagaimana pekerjaan itu berjalan.

String.Source: Captain Veleth told me that Adril Arano, Second Councilor of Raven Rock, wanted to speak to me immediately. I should find him and discover the reason for his urgent message.
String.Dest: Captain Veleth memberitahuku bahwa Adril Arano, Penasehat Kedua Raven Rock, ingin berbicara denganku segera. Aku harus menemukannya dan mencari tahu alasan pesan mendesaknya.

String.Source:
[pagebreak]

Trap by Anonymous

[pagebreak]

saw the gold, and I took it. A different man might not have, I know that, and from time to time, I think back on the hour when I saw the gold and took it. You see, I was hungry. Isn't it ironic. I don't remember much else about that night but the gold and the hunger. I don't remember the name of the tavern, or even the village, but I believe it was somewhere in southern Vvardenfell. I can't really be certain. For some time, I sat dumbly in my chair, my mind occupied with nothing but the pain in my stomach. If you've never been truly hungry from days of no food, you can't know what it's like. You can't concentrate on anything. It wasn't until a figure to my left got up from the table to get a drink and left a stack of gold marks behind that I snapped to awareness. From this moment on, my memory is crystalline. My eyes to the gold. My eyes to the stranger's back, walking calmly toward the barmaid. My hand to the gold. The gold in my pocket. I'm up from the table, and out the door. For just a moment, I look back. The stranger has turned to look my way. He wears a hood, but I can feel his eyes meet mine. I swear, I can scent a smile. Out into the street, and behind some barrels I crouched down, waiting for my pursuer. One benefit of a lifetime running from guards, I know how to disappear. For nearly an hour, I waited there, suffering even more from hunger. You see, I was awake now and I had the means to buy myself a feast. This knowledge tortured me. When I finally got to my feet, I very nearly fainted. I had only enough energy to walk to the other edge of the village to a run-down tavern before collapsing at a table. I think I must have fallen unconscious for a moment before I heard the barmaid's voice. "Can I get you something to eat, sera?" I gorged myself on roasts and pies and huge frothing mugs of greef. As the fog of near fatal starvation began to lift, I looked up from my plate to see a gold-masked stranger looking at me, his vizard glowing by the blinding light of the moon through the window. He wore black leather armor and was a different physique and size from the man I had burgled, but I could tell he knew. I paid for my meal quickly and left. I skirted the edge of the village, through a tiled central courtyard surrounded by the squalid peasant's cottages. There was not a light shining from any window or door. No one was on the streets. I could find no place to hide, so I took the road out of town, heading for the wilderness. Hunger had pushed me on in the days before, but now I felt what I imagined to be the whip of guilt. Or perhaps, even then, it was fear. I fell twice, rushing down the dark path, unused to the slopes and pebbled texture. The sounds of animal life, which I had numbed to, were suddenly very loud in my ears. And there was something else out there in the night, something chasing me. On the side of the road, there was a low wall, and I scrambled over it and hid. I knew enough about concealment to pick a spot where the bulwark sunk slightly so even if someone saw the outline of my figure, he would assume it to be part of the wall. It wasn't long before I heard the sound of running footsteps from more than one person pass me by and then stop. There was a moment of whispered conversation, and one of the people ran back on the path toward the village. Then, silence. After a few more minutes, I peered out from behind the wall. A female figure in a dun gown, wimple, and veil stood in the road. On the other end of the road, blocking the way back to town, was a knight, coated in dark mail. I could see neither of their faces. For a moment, I froze, unsure whether either or both had seen me. "Run," said the woman in a dead voice. The hill behind me was too steep, so I leapt over the wall and across the road in two bounds. Into the night forest I ran, the maddening jingle of the accursed gold in my pocket. I knew I was making so much noise my pursuers could not help but hear me, but now I cared more for putting distance between us than in stealth. Clouds of ash filtered through the moonlight, but I still knew it was too bright to hide. I ran and ran until I felt all my blood pumping in my head and heart, begging me to stop. I was at the edge of the wood, on the other side of a shallow stream from a vast, crumbling house encircled by a rail fence. Behind me, running footfall in the broken, dusty earth. To the south, downstream, a distinct sodden splashing of someone moving nearer. There was no choice. I half jumped and half fell into the mud and dragged myself up the bank on the other side. I rolled under the fence and ran through the open field toward the house. Jerking my head around, I saw seven shadowy figures by the fence posts. The cloaked man I had robbed. The man in the gold mask. The veiled woman. The dark knight. Three others too who had pursued me, but I had never seen. And I thought I was the stealthy one. The moon was entirely hidden in a swarm of ash. Only the stars offered their meager illumination as I reached the open door of the ruin. I slammed and bolted the door behind me, but I knew there could be no protection for very long. As I looked about the ravaged interior of broken furniture, I searched for someone to hide. A corner, a niche where if I stayed very still, no one would see me. A splintered table lying against the wall looked perfect for my purposes. I crawled under it, and jumped when something moved and I heard a frightened old man's voice. "Who's there?" "It's all right," I whispered. "I'm not one of them." His puckered, gnarled hand reached out from the shadow and gripped my arm. Instantly, I felt sleep fall upon me, resist it as I might. The old man's horrible face, the face of the hungry dead, emerged as the moon came out and shone through the broken window. His talon still gripping me, I fell back, smelling his death surround me. The table was thrown back. There stood the seven hunters and a dozen more. No, hunters they weren't. They were harriers who had chased me out of every hiding place, expertly pushing me to the lair of the real predator. He was weak with age, the old man was, not as good at the chase as once he was. A blunt, killing machine. "Please," I said. It was all I could muster. Having enjoyed the sport I offered, he granted me mercy, of sorts. I was not bled dry. I was not cursed by being made one of them, the Berne. I was kept with others, most of us mad with fear, to be aged and tasted at the vampires' whim. We are called cattle. I lost all hope months ago of ever leaving the dank cellar where they keep us. Even if this note finds its way to the outside world, I cannot give enough information about my whereabouts to be rescued, even if some champion were able to defeat the bloodsuckers. I only write this to keep my own sanity, and to warn others. There is something worse than being hungry. Being food.
String.Dest:
[pagebreak]

Jebakan oleh Anonymous

[pagebreak]

melihat emas, dan aku mengambilnya. Orang lain mungkin tidak akan melakukannya, aku tahu itu, dan sesekali, aku teringat kembali pada jam ketika aku melihat emas itu dan mengambilnya. Kau lihat, aku lapar. Bukankah itu ironis. Aku tidak ingat banyak hal lain tentang malam itu kecuali emas dan rasa lapar. Aku tidak ingat nama kedai, atau bahkan desa, tapi aku yakin itu berada di suatu tempat di selatan Vvardenfell. Aku tidak benar‑benar yakin. Untuk beberapa waktu, aku duduk terpaku di kursi, pikiranku hanya dipenuhi rasa sakit di perutku. Jika kau belum pernah benar‑benar kelaparan selama berhari‑hari tanpa makanan, kau tidak akan mengerti rasanya. Kau tidak dapat berkonsentrasi pada apapun. Baru ketika sosok di sebelah kiriku bangkit dari meja untuk mengambil minuman dan meninggalkan tumpukan koin emas di belakangnya, aku terjaga. Sejak saat itu, ingatanku menjadi kristal. Mata ku pada emas. Mata ku pada punggung orang asing itu, berjalan tenang menuju pelayan bar. Tangan ku pada emas. Emas di sakuku. Aku bangkit dari meja, dan keluar pintu. Sekejap, aku menoleh kembali. Orang asing itu berbalik menatapku. Ia memakai tudung, tapi aku bisa merasakan matanya bertemu dengan mataku. Aku bersumpah, aku bisa mencium senyum. Keluar ke jalan, dan di belakang beberapa tong, aku merangkak, menunggu pengikutku. Satu keuntungan dari seumur hidup berlari dari penjaga, aku tahu cara menghilang. Selama hampir satu jam, aku menunggu di sana, semakin menderita karena lapar. Kau lihat, kini aku terjaga dan memiliki cara untuk membeli pesta makan. Pengetahuan itu menyiksa ku. Ketika akhirnya aku berdiri, hampir pingsan. Aku hanya punya cukup tenaga untuk berjalan ke ujung lain desa ke sebuah kedai reyot sebelum runtuh di sebuah meja. Aku rasa aku hampir pingsan sejenak sebelum mendengar suara pelayan bar. "Bolehkah aku menyediakan sesuatu untuk dimakan, sera?" Aku melahap panggang, pai, dan mug besar berisi greef berbusana busa. Saat kabut kelaparan hampir mematikan mulai terangkat, aku menengok piringku dan melihat sosok asing bermasker emas menatapku, visornya bersinar oleh cahaya bulan yang menyilaukan lewat jendela. Ia mengenakan baju zirah kulit hitam dan berpostur serta ukuran berbeda dari pria yang kupencet, tapi aku tahu ia mengerti. Aku cepat membayar makananku dan pergi. Aku melingkari tepi desa, melewati halaman tengah berbatu yang dikelilingi rumah‑rumah petani yang suram. Tidak ada cahaya yang menyinari jendela atau pintu. Tidak ada orang di jalan. Aku tak menemukan tempat untuk bersembunyi, jadi aku mengambil jalan keluar desa, menuju hutan. Kelaparan pernah mendorongku sebelumnya, tapi kini aku merasakan apa yang kupikirkan sebagai cambuk rasa bersalah. Atau mungkin, saat itu, ketakutan. Aku terjatuh dua kali, berlari menuruni jalur gelap, tak terbiasa dengan lereng dan tekstur berbatu. Suara binatang, yang dulu kupadamkan, tiba‑tiba terdengar sangat keras di telingaku. Dan ada sesuatu yang lain di malam itu, sesuatu yang mengejarku. Di pinggir jalan ada tembok rendah, aku memanjatinya dan bersembunyi. Aku cukup tahu cara bersembunyi untuk memilih tempat di mana The Bulwark sedikit tenggelam sehingga meski orang melihat bayanganku, ia mengira itu bagian tembok. Tak lama, aku mendengar derap kaki berlari dari lebih dari satu orang yang melewatiku lalu berhenti. Ada bisikan singkat, dan salah satu orang berlari kembali ke jalan menuju desa. Lalu, hening. Setelah beberapa menit lagi, aku mengintip dari belakang tembok. Sosok perempuan dalam gaun coklat kusam, wimple, dan kerudung berdiri di jalan. Di ujung jalan yang lain, menghalangi jalan kembali ke desa, ada kesatria berdiri dengan zirah gelap. Aku tidak dapat melihat wajah keduanya. Aku terpaku sesaat, tidak yakin apakah salah satu atau keduanya telah melihatku. "Lari," kata perempuan itu dengan suara mati. Bukit di belakangku terlalu curam, jadi aku melompat melewati tembok dan menyeberang jalan dalam dua lompatan. Aku berlari ke dalam hutan malam, dentingan emas terkutuk di sakuku yang mengganggu. Aku tahu suaraku terlalu keras sehingga pengejarku pasti mendengarnya, tapi kini aku lebih memikirkan menjauhkan diri ketimbang bersembunyi. Awan abu menyaring sinar bulan, namun masih terlalu terang untuk bersembunyi. Aku berlari dan berlari sampai terasa seluruh darahku memompa di kepalaku dan hatiku, memohonku berhenti. Aku berada di pinggiran hutan, di sisi lain aliran air dangkal dari sebuah rumah besar yang runtuh, dikelilingi pagar kayu. Di belakangku, jejak kaki berlari di tanah berdebu yang pecah‑pecah. Ke selatan, hilir, terdengar percikan air basah seseorang semakin mendekat. Tidak ada pilihan. Aku setengah melompat, setengah terjatuh ke lumpur dan menyeret diri ke tepi di sisi lain. Aku merangkak di bawah pagar dan berlari melewati lapangan terbuka menuju rumah itu. Memutar kepala, kulihat tujuh bayangan di tiang pagar. Orang berjubah yang kurampok. Pria bermasker emas. Perempuan berselubung. Kesatria gelap. Tiga lainnya yang mengejarku, tapi belum pernah kulihat. Dan kukira diriku yang paling licik. Bulan sepenuhnya tersembunyi di dalam awan abu. Hanya bintang‑bintang yang memberi cahaya redup ketika aku mencapai pintu terbuka bangunan hancur itu. Aku menutup dan mengunci pintu di belakangku, tapi aku tahu perlindungan tidak akan bertahan lama. Saat mengintip interior berantakan dengan perabot rusak, aku mencari tempat bersembunyi. Sebuah sudut, celah di mana jika aku tetap diam, tak ada yang akan melihatku. Sebuah meja pecah menempel pada dinding tampak sempurna untuk keperluanku. Aku merangkak di bawahnya, dan melompat ketika sesuatu bergerak dan kudengar suara orang tua yang ketakutan. "Siapa itu?" "Tidak apa‑apa," ku bisik. "Aku bukan mereka." Tangan keriput berkerutnya menjulur dari bayangan dan menggenggam lenganku. Seketika, aku merasakan kantuk menyerbu, walau kuusah menolaknya. Wajah menakutkan orang tua itu, wajah orang mati kelaparan, muncul ketika bulan muncul dan menyinari melalui jendela pecah. Cakarannya masih menggenggamku, aku terjatuh kembali, mencium bau kematiannya mengelilingi diriku. Meja itu terlempar mundur. Tujuh pemburu dan selusin lagi berdiri. Bukan, mereka bukan pemburu. Mereka adalah harrier yang mengejarku dari setiap tempat bersembunyi, dengan terampil mendorongku ke sarang predator sejati. Dia lemah karena usia, orang tua itu, tidak lagi sekencang dulu. Mesin pembunuh yang tumpul. "Tolong," kataku. Itu saja yang bisa kukatakan. Setelah menikmati permainan yang kutawarkan, dia memberiku belas kasihan, semacamnya. Aku tidak dikuras habis. Aku tidak terkutuk menjadi salah satu dari mereka, si Berne. Aku disimpan bersama yang lain, kebanyakan dari kami gila karena ketakutan, untuk diperlambat dan dimakan sesuka hati vampir. Kami disebut ternak. Aku kehilangan semua harapan berbulan‑bulan yang lalu untuk pernah keluar dari ruang bawah tanah lembap tempat mereka menahan kami. Bahkan jika catatan ini sampai ke dunia luar, aku tidak dapat memberi cukup informasi tentang lokasiku untuk diselamatkan, sekalipun ada pahlawan yang mampu mengalahkan peminum darah. Aku menulis ini hanya untuk menjaga kewarasanku, dan memperingatkan orang lain. Ada sesuatu yang lebih buruk daripada kelaparan. Menjadi makanan.

String.Source:
Mora's Boon: Fully restores your Health, Magicka, and Stamina.
You may only accept one ability from this book at a time.
String.Dest:
Berkah Mora: Sepenuhnya memulihkan Kesehatan, Magicka, dan Stamina Anda.
Anda hanya dapat menerima satu kemampuan dari buku ini pada satu waktu.

String.Source: I've killed Vendil Ulen and stopped the threat against Councilor Morvayn. Vendil had hired assassins from Morrowind known as the Morag Tong to help him with his coup, but fortunately I was able to defeat them in the depths of Ashfallow Citadel. I should return to Adril Arano with the good news.
String.Dest: Saya telah membunuh Vendil Ulen dan menghentikan ancaman terhadap Konselor Morvayn. Vendil telah menyewa pembunuh dari Morrowind yang dikenal sebagai Morag Tong untuk membantunya dalam kudeta, tetapi untungnya saya berhasil mengalahkan mereka di kedalaman Ashfallow Citadel. Saya harus kembali ke Adril Arano dengan kabar baik.

String.Source: Adril Arano has requested my help with what he believes is an imminent threat on Councilor Morvayn's life. He believes members of the Ulen family are present on the island and seek revenge upon Morvayn for executing their ancestor. He's requested that I investigate the identity of any possible assassins, hoping to catch them unaware. For now, I've refused his request, but I should return to Adril when I'm ready to assist him.
String.Dest: Adril Arano telah meminta bantuanku untuk mengatasi apa yang dia yakini sebagai ancaman yang akan segera terjadi terhadap nyawa Councilor Morvayn. Dia percaya anggota keluarga Ulen berada di pulau ini dan mencari balas dendam terhadap Morvayn karena mengeksekusi nenek moyang mereka. Dia meminta aku menyelidiki identitas kemungkinan pembunuh, dengan harapan menangkap mereka tanpa mereka sadari. Untuk saat ini, aku menolak permintaannya, tetapi aku harus kembali ke Adril ketika aku siap membantunya.

String.Source: Bone Meal Albino Spider Pod
String.Dest: Bone Meal Kapsul Laba-Laba Albino

String.Source: Your Thu'um enchants your nearby allies' weapons, allowing them to attack faster.
String.Dest: Thu'um Anda mempesona senjata sekutu terdekat Anda, memungkinkan mereka menyerang lebih cepat.

String.Source:
bjorn
do not come to this place
i have not much self left
the earth will take us both
- h
String.Dest:
bjorn
jangan datang ke tempat ini
ta tidak banyak diri lagi
tanah akan mengambil kita berdua
- h

String.Source: I've been attacked by a group of people claiming to work for someone named Miraak. I need to find out why they're trying to kill me, and so I should look for the boat in Windhelm they used to travel from Solstheim.
String.Dest: Aku telah diserang oleh sekelompok orang yang mengaku bekerja untuk seseorang bernama Miraak. Aku perlu mencari tahu mengapa mereka mencoba membunuhku, jadi aku harus mencari perahu di Windhelm yang mereka gunakan untuk bepergian dari Solstheim.

String.Source: The people of Raven Rock know the name Miraak, saying that he has a temple near the center of the island. I should seek him out and find out why people have attacked me on his behalf.
String.Dest: Penduduk Raven Rock mengetahui nama Miraak, menyatakan bahwa dia memiliki sebuah kuil di dekat pusat pulau. Aku harus mencarinya dan mencari tahu mengapa orang-orang menyerangku atas namanya.

String.Source:
Hrodulf, light and strength,
I feel your words are not your own, and I worry dearly for your health.
I beg of you: please depart that blasted isle and return to Solitude at once! My nights have been almost impossible to bear without you; to lose you would be the death of me.
My love, if you do not return soon, I will come for you.
- Bjornolfr
String.Dest:
Hrodulf, cahaya dan kekuatan,
Aku merasakan kata‑kata mu bukan milikmu sendiri, dan aku sangat khawatir akan kesehatanmu.
Aku memohon padamu: tolong tinggalkan pulau terkutuk itu dan kembali ke Solitude segera! Malam‑malamku hampir tak tertahankan tanpa kau; kehilanganmu akan menjadi kematian bagiku.
Sayangku, bila kau tidak kembali cepat, aku akan datang menjemputmu.
- Bjornolfr

String.Source: The Skaal have been freed from Miraak's control, and his minion has been destroyed. Now that Storn no longer needs to focus on keeping his people safe, he may be able to tell me more about how to find and defeat Miraak.
String.Dest: Skaal telah dibebaskan dari kendali Miraak, dan bawahannya telah dimusnahkan. Sekarang karena Storn tidak lagi harus memusatkan perhatian pada menjaga keselamatan rakyatnya, dia mungkin dapat memberitahuku lebih banyak tentang cara menemukan dan mengalahkan Miraak.

String.Source: All spells cost <15>% less to cast, and magicka regenerates <100>% faster.
String.Dest: Semua spells biayanya <15>% lebih murah untuk digunakan, dan magicka pulih <100>% lebih cepat.

String.Source:
<font face='$HandwrittenFont'> Delvin, Here's the formula for the Improved Bonemold I mentioned in my last letter. Take whatever gold you make from the sale and make sure our little sister is taken care of.
Ingredients: 4 cups of bone dust 1 cup void salts 1 bottle of netch jelly 1 cup of ground stahlrim chips 1 bucket of fresh water
Add the bone and void salts to the water and allow them to soak for at least a full day. Then add the netch jelly and stahlrim chips to the bucket. Stir over a hot flame until the mixture begins to harden. Pour the mixture into the desired mold and set the mold in the center of your forge. Fire the mixture in the forge for at least a half day. Let the mixture cool and then remove from the mold.
Glover Mallory
String.Dest:
<font face='$HandwrittenFont'> Delvin, Berikut rumus untuk Improved Bonemold yang saya sebutkan dalam surat terakhir saya. Ambil segala emas yang kamu dapatkan dari penjualan itu dan pastikan adik kecil kita terurus dengan baik.
